schemas.description: GOGREEN and GCLASS first data release survey catalogues

tables.description: information relevant to each cluster in system in the GCLASS and GOGREEN surveys
selected photometric data for each cluster system in the GCLASS, GOGREEN samples, COMOS UltraVISTA, and SXDF SPLASH fields
contains an entry for every unique object with a GOGREEN or GCLASS spectrum

columns.description: Short name of each cluster.
Longer format cluster name
An integer which is used to identify the corresponding photometry. It is a unique number for each SpARCS and SPT cluster; it is 14 for all COSMOS clusters and 13 for those in the SXDF.

Coordinates, in J2000 degrees, for the best estimate of the cluster centre. For the SPT and SpARCS clusters, this is the location of the BCG. For the COSMOS and SXDF clusters, it is the average position of members as described in §4.2.3 of GOGREEN adn GCLASS Survey: First Data Release paper

Coordinates, in J2000 degrees, for the best estimate of the cluster centre. For the SPT and SpARCS clusters, this is the location of the BCG. For the COSMOS and SXDF clusters, it is the average position of members as described in §4.2.3 of The GOGREEN adn GCLASS Survey: First Data Release paper
Coordinates, in J2000 degrees, for the centre of the GMOS spectroscopic observations (GOGREEN only)
Coordinates, in J2000 degrees, for the centre of the GMOS spectroscopic observations (GOGREEN only)
Position angle, in degrees, for the GMOS spectroscopic observations (GOGREEN only).
Best estimate of the cluster redshift, based on available spectroscopy, including publicly available spectra from other sources not included in this release.
Velocity dispersion in km/s, computed as described in §4.2.3 of The GOGREEN adn GCLASS Survey: First Data Release paper.
Veolicty dispersion uncertainty in km/s, computed as described in §4.2.3 of The GOGREEN adn GCLASS Survey: First Data Release paper.
Name of each GOGREEN GMOS mask, for N from 1 to 6, used to obtain spectra for this program.
Name of each GOGREEN GMOS mask, for N from 1 to 6, used to obtain spectra for this program.
Name of each GOGREEN GMOS mask, for N from 1 to 6, used to obtain spectra for this program.
Name of each GOGREEN GMOS mask, for N from 1 to 6, used to obtain spectra for this program.
Name of each GOGREEN GMOS mask, for N from 1 to 6, used to obtain spectra for this program.
Name of each GOGREEN GMOS mask, for N from 1 to 6, used to obtain spectra for this program.
Name of each GCLASS GMOS mask, for N from 1 to 5, used to obtain spectra for this program.
Name of each GCLASS GMOS mask, for N from 1 to 5, used to obtain spectra for this program.
Name of each GCLASS GMOS mask, for N from 1 to 5, used to obtain spectra for this program.
Name of each GCLASS GMOS mask, for N from 1 to 5, used to obtain spectra for this program.
Name of each GCLASS GMOS mask, for N from 1 to 5, used to obtain spectra for this program.
Name of K-selected photometry catalogue
Name of photometric redshift catalogue
Name of catalogue with stellar mass information
Name of image for filter u for SpARCS and SPT clusters.
Name of image for filter b for SpARCS and SPT clusters.
Name of image for filter g for SpARCS and SPT clusters.
Name of image for filter v for SpARCS and SPT clusters.
Name of image for filter r for SpARCS and SPT clusters.
Name of image for filter i for SpARCS and SPT clusters.
Name of image for filter z for SpARCS and SPT clusters.
Name of image for filter j for SpARCS and SPT clusters.
Name of image for filter j1 for SpARCS and SPT clusters.
Name of image for filter y for SpARCS and SPT clusters.
Name of image for filter k for SpARCS and SPT clusters.
Name of image for filter irac1 for SpARCS and SPT clusters.

Name of the GMOS z-band image, or Subaru pseudo-image, used for mask design. Note the preimages were used for mask design but are not optimally reduced, specifically regarding sky subtraction and astrometry.
Random ID in the range 0.0 => 100.0

Name of the corresponding cluster, when there is an associated photometric catalogue. Objects in the COSMOS or SXDF photometric catalogues are identified with those labels, unless there is a GOGREEN spectroscopic redshift, in which case we use the name of the associated target. Note that SXDF49 and SXDF87 share a field, and are identified here only by SXDF49. Similarly SXDF76a and SXDF76b are identified here as SXDF76.

This is a unique identifier for each object in this table. The first digit identifies the source of the photometry (1: GOGREEN; 2: GCLASS; 3: UltraVISTA/COSMOS; 4:SPLASH/SXDF). The next two digits are the cluster_id column from Table 2. The remaining numbers are the PHOTID identifier in the main photometric catalogues
The ID corresponding to Table 4 for objects with a corresponding GCLASS or GOGREEN spectrum
J2000 positions, in degrees. Calibrated with SDSS DR7 or USNO-b whenever a cluster falls outside of the SDSS footprint.
J2000 positions, in degrees. Calibrated with SDSS DR7 or USNO-b whenever a cluster falls outside of the SDSS footprint.

The spectroscopic redshift for the associated spectrum, if any. (See redshift_quality for the quality flag).  Redshifts without a corresponding Redshift_Quality are copied from the parent (UltraVISTA or SPLASH) catalogue.
Quality flag for associated spectrum in zspec

Photometric redshift from the 68 per cent confidence region. Based on the zpeak output from EAZY (Brammer et al. 2008), where for the GOGREEN galaxies a polynomial correction is applied to improve the correspondence with spectroscopy.
Photometric redshift loweri uncertainty for zphot
Photometric redshift upper uncertainty for zphot

U - V, Rest-frame colours between Johnson U and  V, as measured with EAZY (Brammer et al. 2008). Small offsets, as described in van der Burg et al. (2020), have been applied on a cluster-by-cluster basis to improve correspondence with UltraVISTA. For the COSMOS galaxies the rest-frame colours are from the UltraVISTA catalogue.

V - J, Rest-frame colours between Johnson V and J, as measured with EAZY (Brammer et al. 2008). Small offsets, as described in van der Burg et al. (2020), have been applied on a cluster-by-cluster basis to improve correspondence with UltraVISTA. For the COSMOS galaxies the rest-frame colours are from the UltraVISTA catalogue.
Star/galaxy classification based on colours, as described in van der Burg et al. (2020). Flag is 1 for a star, and 0 otherwise.
SExtractor flag in the K -band.

Manual mask at position of detection, where objects are masked (totmask= 1) if they do not have an image in all available filters for that cluster. Only sources with totmask=0 are included in this compilation catalogue. Photometry for other sources must be obtained from the original catalogues.

Total stellar masses, measured with the FAST (Kriek et al. 2009) code and assuming the best redshift for the object (spectroscopic or zphot). These assume τ-model star formation histories, and are known to underestimate the stellar mass obtained with a non-parametric star formation history, by up to 0.3 dex (Leja et al. 2019). For objects in COSMOS and SXDF the stellar masses are taken from their respective catalogues.

HTM index (order 9 => ~10 arcmin size)
HEALPIX index (Nsides 256, Ring scheme => ~14 arcmin size)
HEALPIX index (Nsides 4096, Nest scheme => ~52 arcsec size
Random ID in the range 0.0 => 100.0
Short name of each cluster; matches name in cluster table

A unique identification number. The first digit identifies the origin of the spectrum: 1 for GOGREEN and 2 for GCLASS. The next two digits correspond to the cluster_id identifier in the Cluster catalogue, that specify the photometric field. The remaining digits are the galaxy ID (only unique for a given field and source).

Target RA coordinates in J2000 degrees. For GOGREEN, these coordinates correspond to the z′ image coordinates used for mask design. These have been transformed to align with the K<sub>s</sub> images; however positions will not match exactly with coordinates in the photometric catalogues.

Target Dec coordinate in J2000 degrees. For GOGREEN, these coordinates correspond to the z′ image coordinates used for mask design. These have been transformed to align with the K<sub>s</sub> images; however positions will not match exactly with coordinates in the photometric catalogues.

This has a value of 1 for GOGREEN primary targets, i.e. those that match our photometric selection criteria.  A value of 3 corresponds to a GOGREEN "mask filler" object, and 4 identifies a GCLASS spectrum.  (OBJClass=2 was reserved for stellar sources used for telluric correction, and these are not included in the catalogue).
The redshift measured from the spectrum

The redshift quality flag. Both quality 3 and 4 are secure galaxy redshifts and can be used for scientific analysis; the difference between them is subjective and not rigorously defined. Quality 2 is a "best guess" but should be used with caution; this includes cases where there is plausible consistency with the photometric redshift, but no clearly identifiable spectral features. Quality 1 means no redshift is available.
This is the science extension number in the fits files with the 1D and 2D spectra (see §6.5 of the survey paper).

Integer that identifies spectra with problems that might compromise the ability to measure a redshift or line indices of a spectrum. Flags are assigned for the following: 1: Mild slit contamination or artefacts that should not strongly affect measurements 2: Non-galaxy-like spectrum and/or image 4: Significant slit contamination from neighbouring objects. Redshift & features may be compromised. 8: Poor telluric correction or sky subtraction 16: Major artefacts or large masked regions that render the spectrum nearly useless.  Flags can be added. So, for example, a flag of 12 means there is both contamination from neighbouring objects, and poor sky subtraction
The signal-to-noise ratio per pixel, measured in the range 7500 < λ < 9500Å. The noise estimate is taken from the VAR array associated with the spectrum.
The signal-to-noise ratio per pixel, measured in the range 7500 < λ < 9500Å. The noise estimate is taken from the rms in the science spectrum over the same range.
The D<sub>n</sub> 4000 index as defined in Balogh et al. (1999). See § 4.2.2 in survey paper.
The D<sub>n</sub> 4000 index uncertainty
The equivalent width of the [Oii] emission line in Å, using the line index definitions in Balogh et al. (1999). Positive values represent emission. See § 4.2.2
Uncertainty of ewoii
The equivalent width of the H δ absorption line, in Å, using the line index definitions in Balogh et al. (1999). Positive values represent absorption. See § 4.2.2 in survey paper
Uncertainty of ewhdelta
The equivalent width of the [Oii] emission line, in &#8491, calculated from the Gaussian fitting model described in Old et al. (2020).
Uncertainty of ewoii_model
The integrated flux of the [Oii] emission line, in ergs/s/cm<super>2</super>/&#8491, calculated from the Gaussian fitting model described in Old et al. (2020).
Uncertainty of f_oii
The star formation rate in solar masses per year, estimated from the [Oii] emission line flux and the stellar mass, using the calibration of Gilbank et al. (2010).
Uncertainty of sfr_oii
The difference in Bayesian Information Criterion used to identify the presence of [Oii] emission (ΔBIC > 10) or its absence (ΔBIC < -10). See Old et al. (2020) for more details.

Applicable only to the 11 SPT and SpARCS clusters in GOGREEN, this indicates likely cluster membership based on the clean algorithm of Mamon et al. (2013). A value of 1 indicates a member, 0 is a non-member, and -1 indicates membership could not be determined.

Applicable only to the 11 SPT and SpARCS clusters in GOGREEN, this indicates likely cluster membership based on the C.L.U.M.P.S. algorithm of Munari et al. (in prep). A value of 1 indicates a member, 0 is a non-member, and -1 indicates membership could not be determined.

A flag that identifies likely cluster members (1) or nonmembers (0). A value of -1 means membership could not be determined. For SpARCS and SPT clusters in GOGREEN, this is the maximum of the member_Clean and member_EM flags. For the five GCLASS clusters we use the membership given in Muzzin et al. (2012).  Finally, for the systems in COSMOS and SXDF we define members as those within 1 Mpc and 2.5σ of the centre, as described in § 4.2.3. of the survey paper
HTM index (order 9 => ~10 arcmin size)
HEALPIX index (Nsides 256, Ring scheme => ~14 arcmin size)
HEALPIX index (Nsides 4096, Nest scheme => ~52 arcsec size
Random ID in the range 0.0 => 100.0
